ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to synthesize all Russian cases, and I learned a lot about sentence structure.

I learned much about Russian culture and what I could expect from living in either St. Petersburg or Moscow.  I learned the valuable skill of quickly picking up concepts and applying them in the following days. Most importantly, I learned the Russian language and learned how to learn own my own.
Although I was originally a bit skeptical about taking a virtual language course, I think I've developed a solid foundational understanding of Russian grammar.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Titus and all of the TFs are outstanding. I think that this course is among the best I have taken at Yale.

The strength of the course is how well it is adapted to online format. I would say that a weakness of the course is the fast paced nature that often times gets in the way of the learning of the language.

Maybe this is because classes were virtual, but I wished we spent more time practicing extemporaneous speaking. Professor Titus would ask each of us one question at the beginning of class (e.g. "What did you do this weekend?"), but other than that, we mostly worked on textbook exercises. Some of those exercises were so simple that they didn't really improve my speaking abilitiesfor example, they might ask us to fill in the blanks but give us the exact phrases we had to insert in the blanks. It would have been helpful if instructors had only selected more challenging textbook exercises. I also preferred it when we went through exercises as a class and weren't given the chance to will them out ahead of time. We often got five minutes to fill in the answers and then went over time; I think this is partly why my writing abilities are far stronger than my speaking abilities.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think all practices that were changed because of the pandemic worked well. I liked that we could take each unit exam on canvas at any time during the day.
I think that the daily, live virtual class is a complete success. I think that the practices used in the pandemic were excellent.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you are looking at this course, you probably already took RUSS110. This class is just as good!
Absolutely. If you want to learn Russian, it is the best. That said, it is a lot of work, so be prepared for that.
Definitely. This class is great for students who have always wanted to learn a foreign language besides their native tongue.

If you're genuinely excited about learning Russian, then absolutely! This course will give you a solid foundation, and there's something so wonderful about waking up every morning and spending 55 minutes speaking Russian. At the same time, keep in mind that this course is a lot of workand the language itself is inherently more difficult for English speakers than romance languages. Only take this course if you're genuinely vested in learning Russian, and be willing to spend a lot of time on it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Online lecture, office hours, videos, module links
